EPA RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

TYSON FOODS ALBERTVILLE, AL


1.    Accidental release prevention and emergency response polices


 To insure safe operation and release prevention at Tyson Foods ALBERTVILLE, AL., this 


facility has implemented The Occupational Safety and Health Administrations Chemical 

Process Safety Management Program 29 CFR 1910.119. All operators of systems containing 

the threshold amount of hazardous chemicals will undergo Chemical Process Safety 

Management training and operator training specific to the system.  To insure proper 

response to emergency situations, Tyson Foods ALBERTVILLE, AL., has implemented 

Emergency Action Plans as required by The Occupational Safety and Health Administrations 

29 CFR 1910.38(a) and Emergency Response Plans 29 CFR 1910.120. All safety personnel and 

operators of the process will be trained in these emergency procedures.


2.    The stationary source and regulated substances handled


At Albertville, AL., we use anhydrous ammonia for our refrigeration system. The maximum 

inventory is 32,949 lbs.  


3.    Worst-Case Scenario A? 


The Albertville, Alabama Poultry Processing facility has an ammonia high pressure 

receiver as the single largest ammonia vessel.  The liquid-full capacity of the high 

pressure receiver is 448.3 cubic feet.  Using the ammonia condensing temperature of 95 

degrees yields an approximate operating pressure of 181 psig and an ammonia liquid 

density of 36.71 pounds per cubic foot.  The calculation of 448.3 cubic feet multiplied 

by the liquid density yields the ammonia capacity of 16,457 pounds.  Using RMP Comp with 

the settings of ammonia liquefied under pressure, urban topography and no passive 

mitigation the distance to endpoint is 1.5 miles.


Alternative Release Scenario A? 


Tyson Foods has chosen the alternative release scenario of a pressure relief valve 

activation.  Pressure relief valve activations historically have been the primary 

release type

within the company based on reports to Environmental Compliance.  The 

scenario chosen was based on a pressure relief valve activation resulting from over 

pressurization of a condenser.    The valve modeled was a Refrigeration Specialties SRH3 

which has an inlet port size of 3/4A? and an outlet port size of 1A? and discharge flow 

rating of 57 pounds per minute (air rating) which converts to 44.53 pounds per minute 

ammonia at a pressure setting of 250 psig.  The typical release duration may not reach 

the property boundaries of most Tyson facilities, though EPA requires the alternative 

release scenarios to reach the boundary.  Tyson chose the release duration of 5 minutes 

in an urban setting to yield a distance to endpoint of 0.1 miles which reaches and 

exceeds the property boundary at the Albertville facility.  


4.    The general accidental release prevention program


This facility complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations Chemical 

Process Safety Management 29 CFR 1910.119 and the Environmental Protection Agencies Risk 

Management Program 40 CFR Part 68. For ammonia systems, Tyson Foods Inc. has adopted the 

International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration guidelines for system operation and 

maintenance. Tyson Foods Inc. uses the IIAR Basic Ammonia Refrigeration Training Series 

for all operators augmented by Tyson Standards and Specifications for design, 

construction and maintenance of refrigeration systems.   


5. Five-year accident history


No reportable accidents in past 5 years. 


6. The emergency response program

A fully trained and equipped Emergency Response Team is on site. This team is trained to 

the Hazardous Materials Responder-Technician response capability in accordance with OSHA 

29 CFR 1910.120 (q). The team is capable of affecting all control measures (both 

confinement operations and containment operations) required to remediate the incident.  

A written Emergency Response Plan has been deve

loped and is on record at the Facility. 

This plan includes Pre-Emergency Planning with Outside Agencies, Personnel Roles and 

Lines of Incident Command Authority, Facility Hazard Analysis and Emergency Prevention, 

Safe Distances and Places of Refuge, Site Security and Control, Evacuation Routes and 

Procedures, Decontamination Procedures, provisions for Emergency Medical Treatment, 

Emergency Notification Procedures, Chemical Response Procedures, Post Incident Critique, 

Personal Protective Clothing and Emergency Equipment.  All Hazmat courses at Tyson 

Foods, Inc., are designed to meet training requirements of the OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 (q) 

(7) and (8).  All ALBERTVILLE, AL. Hazmat Team Members are trained 24 hours initially to 

the Technician level followed by 8-24 hours of refresher training per year under the 

direction of the on-site Hazmat Instructor at the facility.  Each Instructor receives an 

initial 40 hours of training and 8-16 hours per year re-certification training that goes 

to I.C. level.  The training is designed to teach both theory and hands-on training 

giving the person an overall understanding of the nature of hazardous materials and the 

ability to assess and safely respond to the incidents in the Incident Command structure. 

Technician level training includes but is not limited to the following:


A? Knowledge of basic hazards and risk assessment techniques

A? Proper selection and use of appropriate and required PPE for the chemical hazard

A? Terminology associated with Hazmat

A? Advanced site control/security procedures

A? Advanced Containment/Control/Decon procedures

A? Use of Atmospheric Monitoring Equipment and Contaminant Test ProceduresA? 
  Incident Command Structure Roles and Line of Authority

A? Interaction with Local and State Officials

A? Standard Operating Procedures for Clean-up and termination

A? Critique


On Site facility Instructors have completed in excess of 40 hours of Instructor's 

training, achi

eving the Incident Command level, over the past 5 years and have 

instructed their team in approximately 80 hours of training.  All training materials, 

hands-on drills and response procedures have been developed under the direction of the 

Corporate Loss Control Department.  All Team members are taught in Hazard Communication 

to report any observed chemical leaks/spills and odors to their supervisor or lead 

person immediately. Supervisors and Leads are taught to report the above to the Safety 

or Process Manager immediately for further investigation and action by the Hazmat team. 

MSDS information books are accessible to all team members for review.  Enhancements in 

the emergency response program for Albertville are currently underway which will involve 

a greater degree of pre-planning, training and partnership between the Albertville Fire 

Department Hazardous Materials Team and the Tyson Foods response team.  


7. Planned changes to improve safety


The Corporate Process Safety and Risk Management Program will be undergoing upgrades in 

the coming months in 2009 and 2010 that will result in streamlined and consistency 

driven approaches to management of hazardous chemicals covered by PSM and RMP at Tyson 

Foods.  This effort will result in enhanced understanding of programs and ease 

compliance with documentation systems through enhanced electronic tracking and record-

keeping.
